children.value: Gatsby is a static site generator. It generates your site’s HTML pages, but also creates a JavaScript runtime that takes over in the browser once the initial HTML has loaded. This enables other pages to load instantaneously. Read on to find out how that runtime is generated.
Gatsby file is the entrypoint to this section. It dynamically creates a webpack configuration by calling
. This can produce radically different configs depending on the stage. E.g
The config is quite large, but here are some of the important values in the final output.

{
  entry: {
    app: ".cache/production-app"
  },
  output: {
    // e.g app-2e49587d85e03a033f58.js
    filename: `[name]-[contenthash].js`,
    // e.g component---src-blog-2-js-cebc3ae7596cbb5b0951.js
    chunkFilename: `[name]-[contenthash].js`,
    path: `/public`,
    publicPath: `/`
  },
  target: `web`,
  mode: `production`,
  node: {
    ___filename: true
  },
  optimization: {
    runtimeChunk: {
      // e.g webpack-runtime-e402cdceeae5fad2aa61.js
      name: `webpack-runtime`
    },
    splitChunks: false
  }
  plugins: [
    // A custom webpack plugin that implements logic to write out chunk-map.json and webpack.stats.json
    plugins.extractStats(),
  ]
}

There’s a lot going on here. And this is just a sample of the output that doesn’t include the loaders, rules, etc. We won’t go over everything here, but most of it is geared towards proper code splitting of your application.
Once Webpack has finished compilation, it will have produced a few key types of bundles:
which we’ll mostly be discussing in this section. It is configured in
section). In practice, the app and webpack-runtime are always needed together.
This is a separate bundle for each page. The mechanics for how these are split off from the main production app are covered in
This is the entrypoint to webpack that outputs
bundle. It is responsible for navigation and page loading once the initial HTML has been loaded.
works, let’s imagine that we’ve just refreshed the browser on our site’s
page. The HTML loads immediately, painting our page quickly. It includes a CDATA section which injects page information into the
object so it’s available in our JavaScript code (inserted during

/*
<![
  CDATA[ */
    window.page={
      "path": "/blog/2.js",
      "componentChunkName": "component---src-blog-2-js",
      jsonName": "blog-2-995"
    };
    window.dataPath="621/path---blog-2-995-a74-dwfQIanOJGe2gi27a9CLKHjamc";
  */ ]
]>
*/
Then, the app, webpack-runtime, component, and data json bundles are loaded via
The first thing our app does is run the
browser API. This allows plugins to perform any operations before we hit the rest of the page loading logic. For example
It’s worth noting that the browser API runner is completely different to

runs in Node.js and has to deal with complex server based execution paths. Whereas running APIs on the browser is simply a matter of iterating through the site’s registered browser plugins and running them one after the other (see
One thing to note is that it gets the list of plugins from
function which is the same as

, except that instead of generating a new DOM tree and inserting it into the document, it expects that a React DOM already exists with exactly the same structure as the React Model. It therefore descends this tree and attaches the appropriate event listeners to it so that it becomes a live React DOM. Since our HTML was rendered with exactly the same code as we’re running in our browser, these will (and have to) match perfectly. The hydration occurs on the
The hydration requires a new React component to “replace” the existing DOM with. Gatsby uses

. This element is returned to our RouteHandler which hands it off to Reach Router for rendering.
Before hydration occurs, we kick off the loading of resources in the background. As mentioned above, the current page’s resources will have already been requested by
tags in the HTML. So, technically, there’s nothing more required for this page load. But we can start loading resources required to navigate to other pages.
. Given a path, it will find its page, and import its component module json query results. But to do this, it needs access to that information. This is provided by
which contains the list of all pages in the site, and all their dataPaths.
